text: ♪♪ ♪♪ ♪♪ ♪♪ So I would like to talk about one of the number nouns that is pretty fundamental to Buddhism. And it's called the tri-lakshana or bhava-lakshana. I'm going to write something out here. You don't have to be a rocket scientist to figure out that tri means three. Sanskrit and English, you probably know this, but if you don't, it's a pretty cool thing. They're cognate languages. And Pali is a simplified form of Sanskrit. The Buddha didn't exactly speak Pali, but he spoke a language pretty similar. So in essence, the Buddha was a westerner, linguistically. North India is an Indo-European speaking region, and so it's not a coincidence that Sanskrit and Pali words sound like English words. They share a common Indo-European origin. So bhava means existence. Actually, it's related to that word we talked about in the group process today, bhavana. Bhavana means to cause to exist, in other words, to cultivate or meditate. That's the standard Pali word for meditation. Bhavana, to cause to exist. But bhava means existence, existence itself. For example, there's an art motif called the bhava-chakra. Chakra, you know, it means wheel, right? And also centers in our bodies are wheels, right? So they're called chakras. It's not pronounced shakra. Chakra actually has a completely different meaning. That's the name of a god, okay? It's chakra. It's cognate to the Greek kuklos, as in cycle, cyclic, and so forth. It means a wheel. So there's this wheel of existence. So bhava means existence. And according to the Buddha, there are three bhava-laksana. There are three marks of existence. And when they had to translate, whoops, when they had to translate that into Sino-Japanese, for those of you that read kanji, san-so, the three marks of existence, the three characteristics. So I sometimes say that the Buddhists are their own worst PR people. It's almost as though Buddhist language was designed to offend and turn off North American sensibilities because it's so negative-sounding. However, as you meditate, you come to realize there's very, very good reasons why this sort of pessimistic language is used in Buddhism. In fact, I once saw an interesting documentary. Well, it was a series on world religions. And the thing that, when they got to Buddhism, what they found so strange was that there was almost a cognitive dissonance because when you would look at Buddhist doctrines based on what you just see there, you would expect people into Buddhism to be really depressed and unhappy and whatever. And it's like, they're really happy, OK, and whatever. It doesn't seem to match. Well, that's because there's a very deep reason why this somewhat negative language was used by the Buddha. So the three marks of existence, you may know them. Do you know them? Dukkha, Anitya, Anatta. That's the Pali, OK? That's the big three, very famous. In Sanskrit, almost pretty similar pronunciation, Dukkha, Anitya, and Anattma or Nirattma. Translated variously in English, that's why I gave you the Pali and the Sanskrit because I think the translations can be somewhat misleading. I mean, the terms themselves are, you know, strange enough, even in the original language. But some of the English translations can really be a little bit abrasive. Let's go into them one at a time. Dukkha is usually translated as suffering. You probably know that the first noble truth, the Arya Satya, meaning the truth realized by the nobles. Noble is a technical term in Buddhism. Anybody that has become liberated at any level is called a noble person, an Arya Puggala. The truths that noble people realize are called the truths of the nobles. So, the first noble truth, Arya Dukkha Satya, the noble truth of Dukkha. There are a number of ways in which this is an important truth. It's an insight. For one thing, most people don't realize how vulnerable they are and how likely it is that they're going to run into physical and emotional distress in this life. So, there's a huge strategy of avoidance, basically, avoiding the reality that sooner or later the doo-doo is going to hit the fan. Sooner or later, something's going to come up in the mind and body. And we're very vulnerable to this. I once heard this person get up, and this was at a Sundance, and he was talking about he had gotten this telephone call and his boy had been arrested and so forth. And he said, I think I'd like to write a book someday called Life is Just a Telephone Call Away. And I thought, yeah, this guy's got a real Buddhist insight. Stuff's going to happen. And as I say, most people don't take any measures to prepare themselves. None of us are in that category. It's not the only reason we come to this retreat, to retreats like this, but it's one of the reasons, so that when stuff happens, we're not completely just blown away. We have some idea that there's something to do. So, part of the truth of suffering and why it's an insight is that it militates against this denial trip that is, as I say, the standard human coping mechanism for the fact that we all live under this sword of Damocles. You know the story of King Damocles, the Sword of Damocles? He was a king and, or wait, no, I think Damocles wasn't the king. He was somebody that was visiting the king. I could have this wrong, but I think the king was named somebody else. And he was like praising the, oh, how great it must be to be a king, etc., etc. So the king said, well, you want to find out what it's like to be king? I'll let you have a taste of what it's like to be king. So I'd like you to come into this room. So in this room there's like this throne, and he says, okay, I want you to sit down on this throne. The guy looks at it and he says, no way, there's a sword hanging over the throne and it's being held by the wispiest little thread. Okay, could give it any second and fall. He said, I'm not going to sit there, even though it's this beautiful jeweled throne and so forth. And the king said, well, this is what it's like to be king. Yes, you have all this power, etc., etc., but it can be taken away from you in a flash. So to acknowledge that that is in fact our human situation is a very adult thing to do. And it doesn't lead to a bummer or pessimism or nihilism. It leads to the opposite of that. It leads to taking action to prepare ourselves so that when we have to experience the unavoidable physical and emotional pains of this life, they won't have to turn into suffering so much, or maybe not at all. Last night we talked at length about this mature spiritual palate called the taste of purification. And I know these retreats are challenging, but as a result of that we acquire this taste. So that in a sense, by acknowledging the truth of the suffering, we sort of reverse the truth of the suffering. So life can become joyous, independent of conditions, because we know if we run into problems, we know how to nurture ourselves through that taste of purification. So I think that's one level, one aspect of the truth of suffering. Another aspect, from the traditional point of view of Buddhism, and I just present this because this is the traditional point of view of Buddhism, it's not necessarily my point of view. But just so that you'll know, since I'm giving a talk on Buddhist concepts here, of course, traditionally Buddhism assumes that there is reincarnation. The Buddha assumed that and taught accordingly. Of course, the Buddha also assumed that the gods existed. People in his time, just like Socrates and Caesar and all those guys in ancient Europe, believed the gods, Zeus and Jupiter and so forth, the gods exist. For people in ancient India, the gods existed. For the Buddha, the gods existed. And reincarnation was taken as a given. It's therefore part and parcel of early Buddhism, part and parcel of Tibetan Buddhism. Interestingly enough, though, in the Sinified form of Buddhism that you have in East Asia, China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam, Chan, Zen, they don't talk about it so much. They're equally liberated to the people in these other traditions, but interestingly enough, don't seem to talk about it too much. And I don't talk about it too much because, to be honest, it's not part of my direct experience, although I certainly don't think it's a ridiculous notion, and lots of smart people have believed it to be true. In any event, the Buddhist concept of saṃsāra, or cyclic existence, quote reincarnation, I mean, that's maybe not the best word for it because it sort of implies there's something that jumps from karne to karne, but in any event, that's the common word that's used. What I find very interesting is the difference in the Buddhist concept of reincarnation and the Western New Age concept of reincarnation. I will encounter people that very blithely tell me, yes, of course, I believe in reincarnation, and I was an Egyptian princess, and next time around I want to be this, and next time around I want to be that. Well, the former lives are always pretty interesting and cool, okay, and the future lives are also interesting and cool and whatever. But that's not the Buddhist concept of reincarnation. Isn't it nice? We're going to come back. Once again, this is traditional Buddhism, just for your knowledge. The good thing about Buddhism, the one real saving grace of Buddhism that totally distinguishes it from every other religion on this planet is you don't have to buy the whole package, okay? The Buddha himself said you don't have to believe things because I say so. Believe it because it agrees with your experience and follows the canons of logic and of story. So, I mean, if you become Shiite Muslim, you buy the whole Shiite package. If you become a Catholic Christian, you pretty much have to buy the Catholic package, the whole thing. The great majority of religions in the world tend to ask you to buy the whole package. Buddhism is certainly the only major religion in the world that does not ask you to do that. So, in any event, I just share this with you for what it's worth. You know the metaphor of the sea turtle and the plank? Did you ever hear that one? The sea turtle and the board? Okay, so there's a turtle in the ocean somewhere. And also in the ocean somewhere is like this piece of wood, little chunk of wood that happens to have a hole in it. Consider the probability that that turtle, upon sticking his head out of the water, will put his head right through the hole in that plank of wood. They're both somewhere in the ocean, okay? So, what is that probability? Well, it is a non-zero, okay? There is a positive probability, but it's pretty small. It's probably in the order of a double exponential, a negative double exponential, one over ten to the ten. Okay, so that's the probability of getting a life like the one you and I have here now, according to traditional Buddhism. What's the more likely possibility? Well, you may never have heard of J.P. Haldane, but he's one of my heroes. He was one of the founders of mathematical biology. He was an Englishman. He was so offended by the way the English treated the Indians, this is under the Raj, that he became an Indian citizen as an Anglo, so that he would have to live as a second-class citizen in his own country and therefore embarrass, because he was a very major famous scientist, embarrass the establishment. Pretty interesting dude, huh? So someone once asked him, based on his study of biomathematics and so forth, was he able to discern any characteristic of the Creator? And he said, well, but the only thing I can figure out about God based on what I see with life forms and so forth is that God has an inordinate fondness for beetles. LAUGHTER Two out of five things that live on this planet are beetles. Your chances of being a beetle are very high. LAUGHTER OK. Given that that is the nature, if you accept the reincarnation thing, OK, there's a lot of dukkha out there, OK? Everybody thinks they're going to have, like, one of these comfortable North American lives. And even the comfortable North American lives, I mean, look at how miserable the kids are, OK? It's like, whoa, what's wrong with this picture? Dukkha. There's another level to dukkha, one more related to meditative experience. You don't realize until you start to let go of some of the congealing around the sense gates, until that starts to happen, you don't realize how much unnecessary discomfort there is inside our sense gates. As you start to meditate, as you start to unfixate the senses, you come to realize that the nature of suffering is not pain, actually. Suffering is pain when it encounters the coagulation of our coagulating tendencies. And there is an enormous amount of subtle suffering that everybody goes through without even realizing it that causes huge distortions in behavior and perception. And as I say, it's sort of this catch-22. Unless you do something like what we do here, you don't really realize that. But unless you have a hint that that is so, it's unlikely you're willing to do something like this. So as you start to come out of the habits of congealing, you realize how much unnecessary malaise that our habits of consciousness produce. It's easiest to see in the body where pain turns into suffering. And that's going to be your first insight into suffering, which is also, of course, the insight into how to become free from suffering. That's the flip side. That's the positive side. Suffering equals discomfort multiplied by resistance. But that's your first insight. But when you go really, really deep in meditation, you come to realize it's not just a body thing. There's subtle coagulation around the thinking process. And even if that thinking doesn't have any sensations associated with it, when it fixates, when it coagulates, it's a little bit uncomfortable. Then you come to realize that the same is true for hearing and seeing. There's subtle, subtle fixations that cause even what seems to be neutral. I mean, you would say, well, wait. I mean, hearing and seeing, there's no pleasure and pain in that. The pleasure and pain is in your bodily reactions to what you hear and see. But actually, there's subtle, subtle coagulation in our external sense gates that cause them to subtly, subtly, subtly be painful. You don't realize that until you start to enter what are called the formless jhana states, the states beyond form. And then you realize how much dukkha there is in form, just form itself. So there are levels and levels and aspects and aspects to the noble truth of suffering, the first mark of existence. The second mark of existence is—actually, I forgot. What's the traditional order? Dukkha, Anicca, Anatta, like that? It's in that order, right? Dukkha, Anicca, Anatta. So second mark of existence is impermanence. I think I'll talk about that last. Third mark of existence, Anatta. This is really designed to confuse and put people off. Usually translated as no self, not designed. I mean, it has the tendency to do that. It's actually designed to set people free. Usually Anatta is translated no self. You can also get translations like no soul. That's really designed to put people off. But of course, it doesn't mean no self and it doesn't mean no soul. It means no atma. That's a Sanskrit word. Atma has a very specific connotation in Sanskrit. Atma is just the Pali pronunciation of that word. Atma means self as thing. It's not just generic self. It's this perception that we have, also sometimes called technically in Pali the satkaya dhikti, this viewpoint that there is an entity, a thing, called self, this reification of the notion of self. We certainly perceive that there is a thing called a self in us. We perceive that. It is an experience. Of course, we also perceive that it seems as though the earth stands still and the sun goes around it. We know better now. But our ordinary intuitions about how the material world works would be earth is flat and stable. Well, the earth isn't flat and it's not stable. Because we have perceptions to the naive senses, it doesn't necessarily mean that upon closer investigation something rather counterintuitive might not be the case. This thing about self is one of those counterintuitive truths. Because we perceive the sense that there's someone behind our eyes and between our ears, a thing, that does the seeing and hearing and willing and acting, because we perceive that, it then becomes enshrined in our language. Every human language that I'm familiar with, East or West, Modern or Ancient, Tribal or Literate, everyone that I know of has nouns and verbs and there are pronouns and there's an implication of self built right into the grammar. You can't say something like, if you say, who meditates, who gets free, you've already set up a substantive that who can only be answered with a noun or a pronoun, a thing. So the grammar of the question already constrains the answer to something that is illusional. So, I can only say that as the thing called self disappears, the activity called personality becomes more and more freed up. So, the people that talk most vehemently that you must realize no self, tend to have very ebullient personalities. That's because E equals mc squared, the energy that is bound up in the mass of self is thing. When that gets freed up, it becomes a wave of personality doing. Of course, a doing can do and then a doing can come to an end. And then re-arise and then come to an end. And re-arise and come to an end. So, you don't have to worry about that you're going to just become like some sort of vacuous zombie if you realize no self. I know at retreats we pretty much look like zombies, but that's just because we're practicing the no self. That's like just our practice. The real no self, when you first bite into emptiness, no self emptiness, they're very closely related. Basically, emptiness is just no self extended to the world. It's the same basic perception. When you first bite into emptiness, like when you first bite into an apple, you encounter the skin that might not be, the skin is actually not representative of the bulk of the apple. And the first bite that you take into no self and emptiness, it might seem a little flat and vacuous, but I promise you as your teeth sink deeper and deeper into it, you discover immense nutrition therein. All the energy of the universe is in that nothingness. So, the true nature of nothingness, void of no self, is not flat. If I had to describe it, I would say it is springy, which is actually sort of interesting because the air is springy, the gases are springy. 19th century physics knew that, but only 20th century physics knows that space itself is springy. Absolute vacuity itself vibrates. And you know what we call the vibration of absolutely nothing? There's a name for it. It's called light. That's what light is. Light's a wave. A wave of what? Water. The energy is carried through a physical medium called water. Light's a wave of what? Ether? No. There is no ether. Once they thought there must be a wave, there must be a substance carrying it. No, the substance that carries it is absolutely nothing. It's a wave of nothing. The whole electromagnetic spectrum is a wave of nothing. It's very interesting. Maybe reincarnation is true because the Buddha... Well, the Buddha didn't say reincarnation. He described it, this being that is. That's how he described it, this being that is. On the sun, an electron drops one quantum shelf in energy. About eight minutes later, on Earth, an electron in another atom jumps the exact same quantum shelf up in energy. In between, there's absolutely empty time space. This being that is. Interesting, huh? So, the true nature of emptiness is vibratory. It is bouncy. So you don't have to fear the no-self. I remember the first time I had an interview with Sasaki Roshi. I'm paraphrasing, and the conversation took place in Japanese. In essence, he said, Shinzen, you've been a monk in Japan. You know what this whole thing is about. I'm tired of these wimpy Americans. I expect you to become the person that no longer needs to make an object of self or world ever again. Laughter It's like, okay, here's the pistol. Okay, here are the bullets. I'm loading it. Put it to your head and blow yourself away. Except, of course, that's not what he was saying. His words were very, very carefully chosen. Very carefully chosen, okay? He didn't say, you must become the person that no longer makes an object out of self or world. He said, you must become the person that no longer needs to make an object out of self and world. That's freedom, okay? So what is it when you need to make an object out of self and world? Well, that's the fixated perspective. But I still have to say it's pretty scary, you know, to have somebody tell you that. But what would inspire me was that I could see the way he moved by the quality of his voice, where it came from, by the look in his eye. I could see that he has the body language of Ray Charles, basically, who is a person that totally accepts their blindness. They cannot make an object out of the world, and they're fine with that. And he doesn't need to make an object out of the world. That's why his body moves like Ray Charles. So, anyway, I could see that nothing bad would happen as the result of that, nothing bad at all. He'd be functional, he'd be happy, he'd be effective in the world. In fact, lots of good things would happen. So, don't be afraid of no-self. The energy that's bound up in the mass of selfless thing gets freed up to power the personality. Now, the traditional Buddhist way of sort of describing this no-self thing is that when you break it down into its pieces, you'll see that there's just the individual pieces, just the components, and their weaving together creates the illusion of thing called self. And the original Buddhist model was called the five-aggregate or five-skanda model, which I will not go into, but you can go to any Theravada website and you can get a description of those five components. I like to use a somewhat simpler model of body image talk or image talk, touch, feel, same basic thing. I like a somewhat more streamlined model, but the basic insight is the same. However, I once heard Sasaki Roshi say that people in the modern world should not have any difficulty understanding Buddhism because people in the modern world have an advantage over people in the ancient world because people in the modern world have science, and science describes the world as it is, and Buddhism describes the world as it is, and therefore, living in a world where there is science, you have a better chance to understand Buddhism. He actually said that. And here's an example. In order to try to explain this notion of when you break it down into its parts, you see that there's no thing called a self. That's why I have you look at body image talk, OK? Tease them apart. See what happens when you really, really, really keep track of them. See what happens when you lose track of them in terms of your perception of I am-ness. Anyway, the technology of the ancient world didn't really provide a very convincing metaphor for this teaching in Buddhism. The traditional metaphor, you may have read it if you've ever been into Buddhist literature, it's called the metaphor of the chariot. It appears in a very famous scripture called the Milinda Panya, the questions of King Milinda, which I had the privilege to read in the original Pali when I was in graduate school. It's a really cool book. But anyway, it's a dialogue between King Milinda and a Buddhist monk named Nagasena. And this took place in about the second century A.D. in what is now pretty much Afghanistan, which at that time had an amazing hybrid Greco-Buddhist culture. Yes, that's where East met West about 2,000 years ago thanks to Alexander's invasion of India. And King Milinda was actually King Menandros. I don't get a much more Greek name than that, Menandros, Menander. He was a Greek-speaking Buddhist. And in this dialogue between King Menandros and Nagasena, Nagasena tries to convince the king that there is no thing inside him called a self. And he said, it's like a chariot. If you look at a chariot, are the wheels the chariot? And the king says, no, the wheels are not the chariot. Well, is the axle tree the chariot? No, the axle tree is not the chariot. Well, is the body of the chariot the chariot? No. And so he sort of goes through the list of all the parts and then uses that to convince the king that, well, in the same way, there is just matter, feeling, thought, karmic tendencies, and consciousness. There are just these five aggregates, and none of them constitute a self. But when they come together, you know, so when you take it all apart, there's no real chariot. There's just all the parts. There's no real self. There's just the five skandhas. Personally, I find this metaphor rather unconvincing. However, the modern world does provide us with what I think is rather a better metaphor. And although it's probably not the exact situation, it is a lot closer to the situation than this deal with the chariot. Most of you have heard me talk about this. So let's imagine that you've got a modern computer with a color monitor, okay? But for some reason, you're running DOS. I know you'd never run DOS, but let's pretend that you're running DOS. It means you've got just black and white on your screen. So I come into the room and I say, you know all those white spots on your screen, all those white letters and all that? There's no white on your screen. And you say, are you crazy? Just look. There's white. And I say, really? Here's a magnifying glass. We agree this magnifying glass does nothing, but magnify makes things larger. But more importantly, if you know anything about optics, the real thing a magnifying glass does is not so much make things bigger. What's important about a magnifying glass? It starts with an R. Reflect. Action. Resolution. A magnifying glass or any optical instrument has the ability to allow you to take points that would fall together for the naked eye. They are separate, but as far as the naked eye can perceive, they fall together. And it separates those. Vipassana. V means separate. R means to see. Vipassana means resolution. There's a nice little mathematical formula for the resolution power of a lens based on its diameter and its curvature and the frequency of the light that you're using to view, etc., etc. So it's really not magnification. It's resolution. It's separating things that truly are separate, but for the unaided eye, fall together. That's what makes a magnifying glass. So vipassana is the resolving lens that we turn towards the five skandhas or towards body image talk, whatever model you want to use. So we go up to your computer monitor, and with this magnifying glass, we look carefully at the white letters, and what do we see? What do we actually see there? We see red, green, and blue pixels. We see little red, green, and blue dots. There's not any white to be found anywhere on that screen. Now, if you take away the magnifying glass and move away, there's this little optical illusion that takes place that merges those things and creates the very strong perception there is a thing called white on the screen. When you take the magnifying glass and you come close and you look carefully, that perception of thing called white on the screen disappears. There's just these components. I suspect that the insight into no-self is a little bit more related to however this thing with the eye works. No one knows how this works, but somehow when we keep track of what is, we get red, green, and blue. When we lose track of what is, we get white. So what is the ontological status of the white? To what extent does that white exist? To what extent does something that goes away when we look at it carefully and reappears very convincingly when we don't look at it carefully, to what extent can we say that thing actually exists? Well, it turns out that the sense of self as thing is a sensory perception that falls under this category. Now, here's the interesting thing. Not only do I think that this is a little bit more towards the reality of the situation, it actually turns out to be an even better metaphor. Because, OK, now, OK, so you've broke everything down into body image talk, touch-feel image talk, whatever. You've broken everything down into its strands. Now, look carefully at those strands and you will see that they are of the nature of impermanence. Originally in Buddhism, impermanence was linked to the notion of dukkha. The original Buddhist notion of impermanence was that we invest all of our hopes of happiness in things that cannot possibly last. Nothing is going to last. Our bodies aren't going to last. Our loved ones aren't going to last. The objects that give us joy aren't going to last. One of my primary objects of joy is mathematics. It's not going to last. I'm going to get old and dumber and dumber and dumber, and if I live long enough, I'm not going to be able to do it anymore. It's not going to last. You probably don't know who Paul Erdos was. Anybody here ever heard of Paul Erdos, E-R-D-O-S? Well, he was one of the great number theoreticians of the 20th century. There's this great book called The Man Who Loved Only Numbers. It's his life story. He was extremely eccentric. You could either describe him as a mathematical monk or you could describe him as a mathematical bag man, in the sense of a homeless person. He never held a job. He was a genius. He didn't have to hold a job. He was a Hungarian Jew. He spoke 50 languages, just went around the world and had this little black book and had the telephone numbers of every major mathematician in the world. He would just arrive in a city, start calling the mathematicians, say, this is Paul Erdos, I'm in town, let's do some theorems, and they would put him up. He had everything in a little plastic bag. He was really like a street person. But anyway, be that as it may, the reason I mention this is what he wanted put on his gravestone, his epitaph. This is actually true. It is. At last, I'm not getting stupider anymore. So, I'm going to get stupider and stupider and stupider. Stuff's not going to last. But we pin our happiness on the prospect of it lasting. So, the impermanent nature of things was linked to the suffering nature of things. Later Buddhist teachers, however, have looked upon impermanence in a much broader and more positive framework. The U Ba Khin tradition, that vibratory flow that many of you have experienced that seems to break things up for you, to sort of undulate and push the impurities up to the surface and excrete them for you, that is looked upon as an aspect of impermanence. And my own teacher's formulation of impermanence is even broader. For him, impermanence is kriyator spiritus, the creator spirit itself. It is pratityasamutpada, to use the early Buddhist term itself, the condition co-arising, the interplay of yin and yang, of yes and no, of expansion and contraction that molds self and world, is molding self and world, moment by moment, continuous creation, priya yeshme'ayin, as the Jewish mystics described it. So, for him, impermanence is none other than ruach ha-kodesh, the Holy Spirit, as the Jewish mystics would have described it. So, it's chi, it's energy, that creates the world, that manifests the self. So, when you do the early Buddhist deconstruction of self, and you see, oh yeah, there's just the strands, and self as thing goes away, but there's another level of deconstruction. What are the strands made of? What is body sensation? What is touch, feel, image, talk, ultimately, what does that consist of? As you bore down more deeply, you discover it is none other than the flow of spirit itself. And, to the extent that you disidentify with self as thing, you then reidentify with this effortless doing. Zen master Rinzai said, within you, within each flesh and blood body, is that true person that has no position. So, he's a Buddhist, the Buddha said no self, he says true self. Okay? Is it contradictory? That true person that has no position, ah, that's the point, no position. If you have a sense of an I, that's some sort of witness self, it has a position. The true self is just the doing, just the flow of impermanence. And, to the extent that a person has experienced that figure ground reversal, where instead of saying I am the content of mind and body, you say I am the doing that is from which mind and body are arising, to the extent that you've had that experience, to that extent, you can say I am that doing, and that doing is quite immortal. Impermanence is absolutely permanent. Because it's not a thing. There's no way the void will ever, you can't say ever not be, that's not the right adjective to use for the void. Okay? The void gives birth to being. The void contains being and non-being. When being and non-being separate, then the self arises. When being and non-being come back together, the self becomes the all that is nothing. And so, to the extent that a human being has been able to break the experience down into the components and then seen what the nature, the vibrant nature of those components, to that extent, in a sense, paradoxically, it's the impermanence that gives you the immortality. The dying process, I believe, is meant to break down the somethingness of the self. And meant to force us to go through that figure ground reversal. And when we do, to the extent that we have done that, we realize that even though the mind and body are going to pass, that's not only what we are. We are that true doing, okay? The dharmakaya. And to the extent that a person has realized that, then they get what we might call actual immortality, not the mythological sorts of wishful thinking immortalities, but the actual experience. But it's not quite the immortality that people with a fixated self would like, okay? People with a fixated self can only dream of, dream of a fixated immortality. But once you start to get a little vision of this other thing, you realize that you can actually, in a sense, sidestep even death itself.

segments.text: So I would like to talk about one of the number nouns
that is pretty fundamental to Buddhism.
And it's called the tri-lakshana or bhava-lakshana.
I'm going to write something out here.
You don't have to be a rocket scientist to figure out
that tri means three.
Sanskrit and English, you probably know this,
but if you don't, it's a pretty cool thing.
They're cognate languages.
And Pali is a simplified form of Sanskrit.
The Buddha didn't exactly speak Pali,
but he spoke a language pretty similar.
So in essence, the Buddha was a westerner, linguistically.
North India is an Indo-European speaking region,
and so it's not a coincidence that Sanskrit
and Pali words sound like English words.
They share a common Indo-European origin.
So bhava means existence.
Actually, it's related to that word we talked about
in the group process today, bhavana.
Bhavana means to cause to exist, in other words,
to cultivate or meditate.
That's the standard Pali word for meditation.
Bhavana, to cause to exist.
But bhava means existence, existence itself.
For example, there's an art motif called the bhava-chakra.
Chakra, you know, it means wheel, right?
And also centers in our bodies are wheels, right?
So they're called chakras.
It's not pronounced shakra.
Chakra actually has a completely different meaning.
That's the name of a god, okay?
It's chakra.
It's cognate to the Greek kuklos, as in cycle, cyclic, and so forth.
It means a wheel.
So there's this wheel of existence.
So bhava means existence.
And according to the Buddha, there are three bhava-laksana.
There are three marks of existence.
And when they had to translate, whoops,
when they had to translate that into Sino-Japanese,
for those of you that read kanji, san-so,
the three marks of existence, the three characteristics.
So I sometimes say that the Buddhists are their own worst PR people.
It's almost as though Buddhist language
was designed to offend and turn off North American sensibilities
because it's so negative-sounding.
However, as you meditate, you come to realize
there's very, very good reasons
why this sort of pessimistic language is used in Buddhism.
In fact, I once saw an interesting documentary.
Well, it was a series on world religions.
And the thing that, when they got to Buddhism,
what they found so strange was
that there was almost a cognitive dissonance
because when you would look at Buddhist doctrines
based on what you just see there,
you would expect people into Buddhism
to be really depressed and unhappy and whatever.
And it's like, they're really happy, OK, and whatever.
It doesn't seem to match.
Well, that's because there's a very deep reason
why this somewhat negative language was used by the Buddha.
So the three marks of existence, you may know them.
Do you know them?
Dukkha, Anitya, Anatta.
That's the Pali, OK?
That's the big three, very famous.
In Sanskrit, almost pretty similar pronunciation,
Dukkha, Anitya, and Anattma or Nirattma.
Translated variously in English,
that's why I gave you the Pali and the Sanskrit
because I think the translations can be somewhat misleading.
I mean, the terms themselves are, you know, strange enough,
even in the original language.
But some of the English translations
can really be a little bit abrasive.
Let's go into them one at a time.
Dukkha is usually translated as suffering.
You probably know that the first noble truth, the Arya Satya,
meaning the truth realized by the nobles.
Noble is a technical term in Buddhism.
Anybody that has become liberated at any level
is called a noble person, an Arya Puggala.
The truths that noble people realize
are called the truths of the nobles.
So, the first noble truth, Arya Dukkha Satya,
the noble truth of Dukkha.
There are a number of ways in which this is an important truth.
It's an insight.
For one thing, most people don't realize how vulnerable they are
and how likely it is that they're going to run into physical
and emotional distress in this life.
So, there's a huge strategy of avoidance, basically,
avoiding the reality that sooner or later
the doo-doo is going to hit the fan.
Sooner or later, something's going to come up in the mind and body.
And we're very vulnerable to this.
I once heard this person get up, and this was at a Sundance,
and he was talking about he had gotten this telephone call
and his boy had been arrested and so forth.
And he said, I think I'd like to write a book someday
called Life is Just a Telephone Call Away.
And I thought, yeah, this guy's got a real Buddhist insight.
Stuff's going to happen.
And as I say, most people don't take any measures to prepare themselves.
None of us are in that category.
It's not the only reason we come to this retreat,
to retreats like this, but it's one of the reasons,
so that when stuff happens, we're not completely just blown away.
We have some idea that there's something to do.
So, part of the truth of suffering and why it's an insight
is that it militates against this denial trip that is, as I say,
the standard human coping mechanism for the fact that we all live
under this sword of Damocles.
You know the story of King Damocles, the Sword of Damocles?
He was a king and, or wait, no, I think Damocles wasn't the king.
He was somebody that was visiting the king.
I could have this wrong, but I think the king was named somebody else.
And he was like praising the, oh, how great it must be to be a king, etc., etc.
So the king said, well, you want to find out what it's like to be king?
I'll let you have a taste of what it's like to be king.
So I'd like you to come into this room.
So in this room there's like this throne, and he says,
okay, I want you to sit down on this throne.
The guy looks at it and he says, no way, there's a sword hanging over the throne
and it's being held by the wispiest little thread.
Okay, could give it any second and fall.
He said, I'm not going to sit there, even though it's this beautiful jeweled throne and so forth.
And the king said, well, this is what it's like to be king.
Yes, you have all this power, etc., etc., but it can be taken away from you in a flash.
So to acknowledge that that is in fact our human situation is a very adult thing to do.
And it doesn't lead to a bummer or pessimism or nihilism.
It leads to the opposite of that.
It leads to taking action to prepare ourselves so that when we have to experience
the unavoidable physical and emotional pains of this life,
they won't have to turn into suffering so much, or maybe not at all.
Last night we talked at length about this mature spiritual palate called the taste of purification.
And I know these retreats are challenging, but as a result of that we acquire this taste.
So that in a sense, by acknowledging the truth of the suffering,
we sort of reverse the truth of the suffering.
So life can become joyous, independent of conditions, because we know if we run into problems,
we know how to nurture ourselves through that taste of purification.
So I think that's one level, one aspect of the truth of suffering.
Another aspect, from the traditional point of view of Buddhism,
and I just present this because this is the traditional point of view of Buddhism,
it's not necessarily my point of view.
But just so that you'll know, since I'm giving a talk on Buddhist concepts here,
of course, traditionally Buddhism assumes that there is reincarnation.
The Buddha assumed that and taught accordingly.
Of course, the Buddha also assumed that the gods existed.
People in his time, just like Socrates and Caesar and all those guys in ancient Europe,
believed the gods, Zeus and Jupiter and so forth, the gods exist.
For people in ancient India, the gods existed.
For the Buddha, the gods existed.
And reincarnation was taken as a given.
It's therefore part and parcel of early Buddhism, part and parcel of Tibetan Buddhism.
Interestingly enough, though, in the Sinified form of Buddhism that you have in East Asia,
China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam, Chan, Zen, they don't talk about it so much.
They're equally liberated to the people in these other traditions,
but interestingly enough, don't seem to talk about it too much.
And I don't talk about it too much because, to be honest,
it's not part of my direct experience,
although I certainly don't think it's a ridiculous notion,
and lots of smart people have believed it to be true.
In any event, the Buddhist concept of saṃsāra, or cyclic existence,
quote reincarnation, I mean, that's maybe not the best word for it
because it sort of implies there's something that jumps from karne to karne,
but in any event, that's the common word that's used.
What I find very interesting is the difference in the Buddhist concept of reincarnation
and the Western New Age concept of reincarnation.
I will encounter people that very blithely tell me,
yes, of course, I believe in reincarnation, and I was an Egyptian princess,
and next time around I want to be this, and next time around I want to be that.
Well, the former lives are always pretty interesting and cool, okay,
and the future lives are also interesting and cool and whatever.
But that's not the Buddhist concept of reincarnation.
Isn't it nice? We're going to come back.
Once again, this is traditional Buddhism, just for your knowledge.
The good thing about Buddhism, the one real saving grace of Buddhism
that totally distinguishes it from every other religion on this planet is
you don't have to buy the whole package, okay?
The Buddha himself said you don't have to believe things because I say so.
Believe it because it agrees with your experience
and follows the canons of logic and of story.
So, I mean, if you become Shiite Muslim, you buy the whole Shiite package.
If you become a Catholic Christian, you pretty much have to buy the Catholic package,
the whole thing.
The great majority of religions in the world tend to ask you to buy the whole package.
Buddhism is certainly the only major religion in the world that does not ask you to do that.
So, in any event, I just share this with you for what it's worth.
You know the metaphor of the sea turtle and the plank?
Did you ever hear that one? The sea turtle and the board?
Okay, so there's a turtle in the ocean somewhere.
And also in the ocean somewhere is like this piece of wood,
little chunk of wood that happens to have a hole in it.
Consider the probability that that turtle, upon sticking his head out of the water,
will put his head right through the hole in that plank of wood.
They're both somewhere in the ocean, okay?
So, what is that probability?
Well, it is a non-zero, okay?
There is a positive probability, but it's pretty small.
It's probably in the order of a double exponential,
a negative double exponential, one over ten to the ten.
Okay, so that's the probability of getting a life like the one you and I have here now,
according to traditional Buddhism.
What's the more likely possibility?
Well, you may never have heard of J.P. Haldane, but he's one of my heroes.

embarrass the establishment.
Pretty interesting dude, huh?
So someone once asked him, based on his study of biomathematics and so forth,

is that God has an inordinate fondness for beetles.

OK.
Given that that is the nature, if you accept the reincarnation thing, OK,
there's a lot of dukkha out there, OK?
Everybody thinks they're going to have, like,
one of these comfortable North American lives.
And even the comfortable North American lives,
I mean, look at how miserable the kids are, OK?
It's like, whoa, what's wrong with this picture?
Dukkha.
There's another level to dukkha,
one more related to meditative experience.
You don't realize until you start to let go
of some of the congealing around the sense gates,
until that starts to happen,
you don't realize how much unnecessary discomfort there is
inside our sense gates.
As you start to meditate, as you start to unfixate the senses,
you come to realize that the nature of suffering is not pain, actually.
Suffering is pain when it encounters the coagulation
of our coagulating tendencies.
And there is an enormous amount of subtle suffering
that everybody goes through without even realizing it
that causes huge distortions in behavior and perception.
And as I say, it's sort of this catch-22.
Unless you do something like what we do here,
you don't really realize that.
But unless you have a hint that that is so,
it's unlikely you're willing to do something like this.
So as you start to come out of the habits of congealing,
you realize how much unnecessary malaise
that our habits of consciousness produce.
It's easiest to see in the body where pain turns into suffering.
And that's going to be your first insight into suffering,
which is also, of course, the insight into how to become free from suffering.
That's the flip side. That's the positive side.
Suffering equals discomfort multiplied by resistance.
But that's your first insight.
But when you go really, really deep in meditation,
you come to realize it's not just a body thing.
There's subtle coagulation around the thinking process.
And even if that thinking doesn't have any sensations associated with it,
when it fixates, when it coagulates, it's a little bit uncomfortable.
Then you come to realize that the same is true for hearing and seeing.
There's subtle, subtle fixations that cause even what seems to be neutral.
I mean, you would say, well, wait.
I mean, hearing and seeing, there's no pleasure and pain in that.
The pleasure and pain is in your bodily reactions to what you hear and see.
But actually, there's subtle, subtle coagulation in our external sense gates
that cause them to subtly, subtly, subtly be painful.
You don't realize that until you start to enter what are called the formless jhana states,
the states beyond form.
And then you realize how much dukkha there is in form, just form itself.
So there are levels and levels and aspects and aspects to the noble truth of suffering,
the first mark of existence.
The second mark of existence is—actually, I forgot.
What's the traditional order? Dukkha, Anicca, Anatta, like that?
It's in that order, right? Dukkha, Anicca, Anatta.
So second mark of existence is impermanence.
I think I'll talk about that last.
Third mark of existence, Anatta.
This is really designed to confuse and put people off.
Usually translated as no self, not designed.
I mean, it has the tendency to do that.
It's actually designed to set people free.
Usually Anatta is translated no self.
You can also get translations like no soul.
That's really designed to put people off.
But of course, it doesn't mean no self and it doesn't mean no soul.
It means no atma.
That's a Sanskrit word.
Atma has a very specific connotation in Sanskrit.
Atma is just the Pali pronunciation of that word.
Atma means self as thing.
It's not just generic self.
It's this perception that we have,
also sometimes called technically in Pali the satkaya dhikti,
this viewpoint that there is an entity, a thing, called self,
this reification of the notion of self.
We certainly perceive that there is a thing called a self in us.
We perceive that.
It is an experience.
Of course, we also perceive that it seems as though the earth stands still
and the sun goes around it.
We know better now.
But our ordinary intuitions about how the material world works
would be earth is flat and stable.
Well, the earth isn't flat and it's not stable.
Because we have perceptions to the naive senses,
it doesn't necessarily mean that upon closer investigation
something rather counterintuitive might not be the case.
This thing about self is one of those counterintuitive truths.
Because we perceive the sense that there's someone behind our eyes
and between our ears, a thing,
that does the seeing and hearing and willing and acting,
because we perceive that, it then becomes enshrined in our language.
Every human language that I'm familiar with,
East or West, Modern or Ancient, Tribal or Literate,
everyone that I know of has nouns and verbs and there are pronouns
and there's an implication of self built right into the grammar.
You can't say something like, if you say,
who meditates, who gets free, you've already set up a substantive
that who can only be answered with a noun or a pronoun, a thing.
So the grammar of the question already constrains the answer
to something that is illusional.
So, I can only say that as the thing called self disappears,
the activity called personality becomes more and more freed up.
So, the people that talk most vehemently that you must realize no self,
tend to have very ebullient personalities.
That's because E equals mc squared,
the energy that is bound up in the mass of self is thing.
When that gets freed up, it becomes a wave of personality doing.
Of course, a doing can do and then a doing can come to an end.
And then re-arise and then come to an end.
And re-arise and come to an end.
So, you don't have to worry about that you're going to just become
like some sort of vacuous zombie if you realize no self.
I know at retreats we pretty much look like zombies,
but that's just because we're practicing the no self.
That's like just our practice.
The real no self, when you first bite into emptiness,
no self emptiness, they're very closely related.
Basically, emptiness is just no self extended to the world.
It's the same basic perception.
When you first bite into emptiness, like when you first bite into an apple,
you encounter the skin that might not be,
the skin is actually not representative of the bulk of the apple.
And the first bite that you take into no self and emptiness,
it might seem a little flat and vacuous,
but I promise you as your teeth sink deeper and deeper into it,
you discover immense nutrition therein.
All the energy of the universe is in that nothingness.
So, the true nature of nothingness, void of no self, is not flat.
If I had to describe it, I would say it is springy,
which is actually sort of interesting because the air is springy,
the gases are springy.
19th century physics knew that, but only 20th century physics
knows that space itself is springy.
Absolute vacuity itself vibrates.
And you know what we call the vibration of absolutely nothing?
There's a name for it.
It's called light. That's what light is.
Light's a wave. A wave of what?
Water. The energy is carried through a physical medium called water.
Light's a wave of what? Ether? No.
There is no ether.
Once they thought there must be a wave, there must be a substance carrying it.
No, the substance that carries it is absolutely nothing.
It's a wave of nothing.
The whole electromagnetic spectrum is a wave of nothing.
It's very interesting.
Maybe reincarnation is true because the Buddha...
Well, the Buddha didn't say reincarnation.
He described it, this being that is.
That's how he described it, this being that is.
On the sun, an electron drops one quantum shelf in energy.
About eight minutes later, on Earth, an electron in another atom
jumps the exact same quantum shelf up in energy.
In between, there's absolutely empty time space.
This being that is.
Interesting, huh?
So, the true nature of emptiness is vibratory.
It is bouncy.
So you don't have to fear the no-self.
I remember the first time I had an interview with Sasaki Roshi.
I'm paraphrasing, and the conversation took place in Japanese.
In essence, he said,
Shinzen, you've been a monk in Japan.
You know what this whole thing is about.
I'm tired of these wimpy Americans.
I expect you to become the person that no longer needs
to make an object of self or world ever again.
Laughter
It's like, okay, here's the pistol.
Okay, here are the bullets. I'm loading it.
Put it to your head and blow yourself away.
Except, of course, that's not what he was saying.
His words were very, very carefully chosen.
Very carefully chosen, okay?
He didn't say, you must become the person that no longer
makes an object out of self or world.
He said, you must become the person that no longer needs
to make an object out of self and world.
That's freedom, okay?
So what is it when you need to make an object out of self and world?
Well, that's the fixated perspective.
But I still have to say it's pretty scary, you know,
to have somebody tell you that.
But what would inspire me was that I could see the way he moved
by the quality of his voice, where it came from,
by the look in his eye.
I could see that he has the body language of Ray Charles, basically,
who is a person that totally accepts their blindness.
They cannot make an object out of the world,
and they're fine with that.
And he doesn't need to make an object out of the world.
That's why his body moves like Ray Charles.
So, anyway, I could see that nothing bad would happen
as the result of that, nothing bad at all.
He'd be functional, he'd be happy, he'd be effective in the world.
In fact, lots of good things would happen.
So, don't be afraid of no-self.
The energy that's bound up in the mass of selfless thing gets freed up
to power the personality.
Now, the traditional Buddhist way of sort of describing this no-self thing
is that when you break it down into its pieces,
you'll see that there's just the individual pieces, just the components,
and their weaving together creates the illusion of thing called self.
And the original Buddhist model was called the five-aggregate
or five-skanda model, which I will not go into,
but you can go to any Theravada website
and you can get a description of those five components.
I like to use a somewhat simpler model of body image talk or image talk,
touch, feel, same basic thing.
I like a somewhat more streamlined model,
but the basic insight is the same.
However, I once heard Sasaki Roshi say that people in the modern world
should not have any difficulty understanding Buddhism
because people in the modern world have an advantage over people in the ancient world
because people in the modern world have science,
and science describes the world as it is,
and Buddhism describes the world as it is,
and therefore, living in a world where there is science,
you have a better chance to understand Buddhism.
He actually said that.
And here's an example.
In order to try to explain this notion of when you break it down into its parts,
you see that there's no thing called a self.
That's why I have you look at body image talk, OK?
Tease them apart.
See what happens when you really, really, really keep track of them.
See what happens when you lose track of them
in terms of your perception of I am-ness.
Anyway, the technology of the ancient world
didn't really provide a very convincing metaphor
for this teaching in Buddhism.
The traditional metaphor, you may have read it
if you've ever been into Buddhist literature,
it's called the metaphor of the chariot.
It appears in a very famous scripture called the Milinda Panya,
the questions of King Milinda,
which I had the privilege to read in the original Pali
when I was in graduate school.
It's a really cool book.
But anyway, it's a dialogue between King Milinda
and a Buddhist monk named Nagasena.
And this took place in about the second century A.D.
in what is now pretty much Afghanistan,
which at that time had an amazing hybrid Greco-Buddhist culture.
Yes, that's where East met West about 2,000 years ago
thanks to Alexander's invasion of India.
And King Milinda was actually King Menandros.
I don't get a much more Greek name than that, Menandros, Menander.
He was a Greek-speaking Buddhist.
And in this dialogue between King Menandros and Nagasena,
Nagasena tries to convince the king
that there is no thing inside him called a self.
And he said, it's like a chariot.
If you look at a chariot, are the wheels the chariot?
And the king says, no, the wheels are not the chariot.
Well, is the axle tree the chariot?
No, the axle tree is not the chariot.
Well, is the body of the chariot the chariot?
No. And so he sort of goes through the list of all the parts
and then uses that to convince the king that,
well, in the same way, there is just matter, feeling, thought,
karmic tendencies, and consciousness.
There are just these five aggregates,
and none of them constitute a self.
But when they come together, you know,
so when you take it all apart, there's no real chariot.
There's just all the parts.
There's no real self. There's just the five skandhas.
Personally, I find this metaphor rather unconvincing.
However, the modern world does provide us with
what I think is rather a better metaphor.
And although it's probably not the exact situation,
it is a lot closer to the situation than this deal with the chariot.
Most of you have heard me talk about this.
So let's imagine that you've got a modern computer
with a color monitor, okay?
But for some reason, you're running DOS.
I know you'd never run DOS, but let's pretend that you're running DOS.
It means you've got just black and white on your screen.
So I come into the room and I say,
you know all those white spots on your screen,
all those white letters and all that?
There's no white on your screen.
And you say, are you crazy? Just look. There's white.
And I say, really? Here's a magnifying glass.
We agree this magnifying glass does nothing,
but magnify makes things larger.
But more importantly, if you know anything about optics,
the real thing a magnifying glass does is not so much make things bigger.
What's important about a magnifying glass?
It starts with an R.
Reflect.
Action.
Resolution.
A magnifying glass or any optical instrument
has the ability to allow you to take points
that would fall together for the naked eye.
They are separate, but as far as the naked eye can perceive,
they fall together.
And it separates those.
Vipassana. V means separate.
R means to see.
Vipassana means resolution.
There's a nice little mathematical formula
for the resolution power of a lens
based on its diameter and its curvature
and the frequency of the light that you're using to view, etc., etc.
So it's really not magnification.
It's resolution.
It's separating things that truly are separate,
but for the unaided eye, fall together.
That's what makes a magnifying glass.
So vipassana is the resolving lens
that we turn towards the five skandhas
or towards body image talk,
whatever model you want to use.
So we go up to your computer monitor,
and with this magnifying glass,
we look carefully at the white letters,
and what do we see?
What do we actually see there?
We see red, green, and blue pixels.
We see little red, green, and blue dots.
There's not any white to be found anywhere on that screen.
Now, if you take away the magnifying glass and move away,
there's this little optical illusion that takes place
that merges those things
and creates the very strong perception
there is a thing called white on the screen.
When you take the magnifying glass and you come close
and you look carefully,
that perception of thing called white on the screen disappears.
There's just these components.
I suspect that the insight into no-self
is a little bit more related to
however this thing with the eye works.
No one knows how this works,
but somehow when we keep track of what is,
we get red, green, and blue.
When we lose track of what is, we get white.
So what is the ontological status of the white?
To what extent does that white exist?
To what extent does something that goes away
when we look at it carefully
and reappears very convincingly
when we don't look at it carefully,
to what extent can we say that thing actually exists?
Well, it turns out that the sense of self as thing
is a sensory perception that falls under this category.
Now, here's the interesting thing.
Not only do I think that this is a little bit more
towards the reality of the situation,
it actually turns out to be an even better metaphor.
Because, OK, now, OK, so you've broke everything down
into body image talk, touch-feel image talk, whatever.
You've broken everything down into its strands.
Now, look carefully at those strands
and you will see that they are of the nature of impermanence.
Originally in Buddhism, impermanence was linked
to the notion of dukkha.
The original Buddhist notion of impermanence was
that we invest all of our hopes of happiness
in things that cannot possibly last.
Nothing is going to last.
Our bodies aren't going to last.
Our loved ones aren't going to last.
The objects that give us joy aren't going to last.
One of my primary objects of joy is mathematics.
It's not going to last.
I'm going to get old and dumber and dumber and dumber,
